newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden to spend 9.0 bln crowns on energy programme.
newsitem.headline: Sweden to spend 9.0 bln crowns on energy programme.

text.p: Sweden's government is to spend nine billion crowns over the next seven years on energy projects, mainly to develop alternatives to nuclear power as it phases out its Barseback plant from 1998.
A proposal published on Friday said that the means of financing the spending would be detailed in the April 15 budget proposal.
Among draft provisions is a budget subsidy of up to 25 percent of the cost of setting up biofuel-powered heating plants. Cost of the subsidies is budgeted at 450 million crowns.
The government is also alloting 300 million crowns for subsidies of up to 15 percent on investments in wind power stations with an output of at least 200 kilowatts.
The closing of Barseback would not affect electricity prices to any great extent, the proposal said.
"The government estimates that the phasing out of Barseback can be done without the general price level being notably affected," it said.
The document aslo said that the government would make better use of natural gas, improve generation and distribution of electricity in the south and reform its system of energy taxes.

"Taxes on energy for industry should be considered whereby power used in the production process would be taxed at a lower rate than that used to heat premises," it said, adding that it would provide further details by the April 15 budget draft.
